channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Says 5 Arab Countries Took Part in Its Airstrikes Inside Syria
item.description: The United States said Bahrain, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates “participated in or supported” the attack on Islamic State targets.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: As China’s Antigraft Efforts Increase, a Call for Padded Interrogation Rooms
item.description: The orders for the rooms, which are intended to prevent officials suspected of corruption from injuring themselves, come amid a huge increase in the number of graft cases under investigation in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A padded interrogation room, where the higher seats are reserved for investigators and the lower one for the suspected corrupt official, in a photograph from 2011.

item.title: Israeli Forces Kill 2 Suspects in Killing of Jewish Teenagers
item.description: A military spokesman said that Marwan Qawasmeh and Amer Abu Aisha were believed to have been killed in a shootout in the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Israel Says It Shot Down Syrian Aircraft
item.description: The military said that a Russian-made fighter jet had “infiltrated into Israeli airspace” and that a Patriot air-defense missile had intercepted the aircraft.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Monitors of Afghan Vote Are Said to Back Secrecy
item.description: Western officials observing the election pressed for the final numbers to be withheld, as demanded by the losing candidate before he joined a unity government, multiple sources said.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Afghan schoolgirls gathered in Kabul on Monday for Ashraf Ghani’s first public appearance since he was declared president-elect.

item.title: China Court Sentences Uighur Scholar to Life in Separatism Case
item.description: The punishment of Ilham Tohti, a professor widely considered to be a moderate voice among ethnic Uighurs, was among the harshest imposed on a political dissident in years.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Protesters Take Inspiration from Paris to Taipei
item.description: Students in Hong Kong are gearing up for their own civil disobedience, with plans to stage sit-in protests in the city’s Central business district in coming days and weeks.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Rallying at Chinese University of Hong Kong on Monday, the beginning of a weeklong boycott of classes to protest Beijing's restrictions on choosing the city's next leader.

item.title: Airstrikes by U.S. and Allies Hit ISIS Targets in Syria
item.description: Airstrikes, conducted with several Arab allies, unleashed a torrent of cruise missiles and precision-guided bombs on the militants’ de facto capital, Raqqa, Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Raqqa Media Center, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Fighters for ISIS during a parade in Raqqa, Syria.

item.title: Fresh Graves Point to Undercount of Ebola Toll
item.description: While the Sierra Leone Health Ministry confirms 10 Ebola deaths, a Freetown cemetery says it has added 110 graves in eight days alone.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: James Hamilton said of burying Ebola victims in Sierra Leone, “We will need much more space.”

item.title: New Video in ISIS ‘Lecture Series’ by John Cantlie
item.description: The terrorist group issued a new installment in its propaganda “lecture series” delivered by the British hostage.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: Health Agency’s New Assessment of the Epidemic Is More Dire Still
item.description: New figures by the World Health Organization suggest the Ebola virus could become a constant presence in West Africa, and could reach more than 20,000 cases by Nov. 2.
item.dc:creator: By DENISE GRADY

item.title: Syrian Opposition Leader Calls on U.S. to Strike Militants From Air
item.description: The leader of the moderate Syrian opposition appealed for American airstrikes to halt the fierce attacks by militants from the Islamic State against Kurdish communities in northern Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Romania: Spotlight Shines on Spies
item.description: The director of Romania’s Foreign Intelligence Agency, Teodor Melescanu, resigned Monday to run for president in the Nov. 2 election.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Memo From Ukraine: For Many, a Nation That Seems Less Free From Moscow’s Dominance Than Ever
item.description: Many politicians and analysts say that Ukraine has capitulated to Russia and that President Vladimir V. Putin won what he wanted to win in the attacks on Ukraine — a shaky and less sovereign nation.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: United Nations General Assembly: Submit Your Questions on the United Nations Meetings
item.description: New York Times reporters answer questions on the United Nations climate summit, the 69th session of the General Assembly and other topics.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: United Nations General Assembly: What to Expect From Narendra Modi at the United Nations
item.description: Since taking power in May, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India has had runaway success with major speeches in part because of their character – colloquial, earthy and extemporaneous. Will that tone translate to the United Nations General Assembly?
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India.

item.title: U.S. Asks U.N. to Add Names to Sanctions List
item.description: The United States and France have asked the Security Council to impose sanctions on as many as 15 people suspected of ties to terrorism, including the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Turkish President Hints That Prisoner Exchange Won Release of Hostages Held by ISIS
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, speaking in New York, said Turkey’s historical position made his country well suited to helping solve conflicts in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Oleg Ivanovsky, Soviets’ Space-Age Designer, Dies at 92
item.description: Mr. Ivanovsky worked on the first satellite to orbit Earth and the craft that carried the first man into space.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE WEBER
item.media:credit: NPO Lavochkin Museum, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Oleg Ivanovsky, right, with Yuri Gagarin on April 12, 1961.

item.title: Arab Bank Liable for Supporting Terrorist Efforts, Jury Finds
item.description: The closely watched case in New York City was the first civil case brought against a bank under the Anti-Terrorism Act to go to trial, and the verdict was expected to have a broad impact.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHANIE CLIFFORD

item.title: Group Backing Islamic State Vows to Kill French Citizen
item.description: The kidnapping in Algeria by jihadists followed a call by ISIS to begin retaliatory attacks on Westerners.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: Ukraine’s Neglected and Battered Army Inspires Citizens to Pitch In
item.description: As casualties have mounted among Ukraine’s outgunned soldiers, citizens and support groups for wounded soldiers have begun to rally behind their army in a rush of patriotic feeling.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wounded member of a militia backing the Ukrainian government talked to a psychologist in a hospital in Dnipropetrovsk. Such forces vary widely in ability.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Jörg Wuttke on the Future of China’s Economy
item.description: Nearly a year after President Xi Jinping announced that China’s economy would increasingly be guided by market forces, many foreign companies are finding life more difficult.
item.category: European Union Chamber of Commerce in China
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Inside a BMW factory in Shenyang, Liaoning Province. The German carmaker is among the foreign companies that have faced inquiries in China over pricing and sales policies.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Price of Abandoning Yemen
item.description: Pro-Iran rebels have taken charge. The victim is democracy.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By IBRAHIM SHARQIEH

item.title: Israel: Court Condemns Policy of Detaining Migrants
item.description: An Israeli court on Monday condemned the government’s policy of detaining illegal African migrants captured in the Negev Desert, ordering that a detention center be closed within three months and banning new detentions for a year.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
